message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The medial pectoral nerve provides motor innervation to the pectoralis major muscle and damage to this nerve during mastectomy can cause atrophy of the muscle. Damage to the other nerves mentioned would not cause atrophy of the lower lateral pectoralis major muscle.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The lower lateral pectoralis major muscle is innervated by the medial pectoral nerve, which can be damaged during mastectomy. Long thoracic nerve damage can cause winged scapula. Intercostobrachial nerve damage can cause posterior arm pain. Lateral pectoral nerve damage can cause weakness in pectoralis major muscle.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The atrophy of the lower lateral pectoralis major muscle suggests damage to the medial pectoral nerve, which supplies innervation to that muscle. The long thoracic nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle, while the intercostobrachial nerve and the lateral pectoral nerve innervate the skin of the axilla and the pectoral region, respectively.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The lower lateral pectoralis major muscle is innervated by the medial pectoral nerve, which is at risk of damage during mastectomy. The other options do not directly innervate the lower lateral pectoralis major muscle.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The atrophy of the medial part of the pectoralis major muscle suggests damage to the medial pectoral nerve, which supplies the pectoralis major and pectoralis minor muscles. None of the other options supply the pectoralis major muscle.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The pectoralis major muscle is innervated by the medial and lateral pectoral nerves. Atrophy of the lower lateral pectoralis major muscle suggests damage to the medial pectoral nerve during mastectomy. The other options do not innervate the pectoralis major muscle or are not associated with atrophy in this area.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The lower lateral pectoralis major muscle is supplied by the medial pectoral nerve, so damage to this nerve during mastectomy is the most likely cause of the atrophy. None of the other nerves mentioned supply this area.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The atrophy of the lower lateral pectoralis major muscle suggests damage to the medial pectoral nerve, which supplies the muscle. The other options either supply different muscles or are not typically affected during mastectomy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the atrophy and the fact that it is on the same side as the mastectomy suggests that the medial pectoral nerve was damaged during the surgery. The other options do not innervate the lower lateral pectoralis major muscle.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The medial pectoral nerve innervates the pectoralis major and minor muscles, and damage to this nerve during mastectomy is a known cause of atrophy of the lower lateral pectoralis major muscle. The other nerves listed do not innervate the pectoralis major muscle in the area of atrophy.
